importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news publication reflects the current state of humanitarian aid delivery to Gaza, highlighting the urgency and immediacy of the food supply shortfall following the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current time frame is critical because it marks the immediate post-ceasefire period, during which humanitarian access and food delivery are being assessed and expanded, directly impacting the lives of Gazans.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza remain far below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily due to limited border crossings.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings—Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara—are currently operational, restricting food access to southern and central Gaza.
The WFP has expanded food distribution points to 26, up from five, but still falls short of the target of 145 distribution points needed to cover the entire Gaza Strip.
The US-brokered ceasefire under President Donald Trump is seen as vital for sustaining humanitarian access and preventing famine, especially in northern Gaza.
Humanitarian aid is reaching northern Gaza only in limited, fragmented ways via the south, and the WFP has not been granted access to the Salah al-Din Street corridor.
Hamas has agreed to hand over the remains of 13 of 28 Israeli captives, with two more scheduled to be delivered, which may influence future easing of border restrictions.
Many Gazans are storing food supplies due to uncertainty about the duration of the ceasefire and the risk of renewed conflict.
Current food deliveries are sufficient for about half a million people for two weeks, indicating a severe and unsustainable shortfall in long-term food security.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for coordinating food aid to people in crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to the article as it reports on the ongoing food supply crisis in Gaza and advocates for more border crossings to increase aid delivery.

namedEntities.name: Gaza Strip
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian territory under Israeli control, currently experiencing a severe humanitarian crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Gaza Strip is the primary location of the food supply issue, with the article detailing the lack of food access due to limited crossings and war-related destruction.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza in the southern part of the Strip.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crossing is one of only two currently operational, limiting food access to southern Gaza and affecting overall aid distribution.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim in Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza in central Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crossing is the other operational point, enabling food entry into central Gaza, but remains insufficient to meet full needs.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south street in Gaza, which is currently blocked to humanitarian access.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been granted permission to use this corridor, limiting access to northern Gaza and preventing aid from reaching key population centers.

namedEntities.name: US President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who brokered a ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s 20-point peace plan is cited as a framework for allowing full humanitarian aid into Gaza, making his role central to the ceasefire and aid access discussions.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister who has stated that the Rafah crossing remains closed until Hamas returns the captives' bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Netanyahu’s position on closing Rafah crossing ties the humanitarian crisis to political conditions, such as the return of captives, affecting aid flow.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant group that holds political and military influence in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is directly involved in the negotiation of prisoner releases and the reopening of crossings, which in turn affects humanitarian access to Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A military wing of Hamas responsible for carrying out attacks and public statements.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Qassam Brigades announced the exhumation and handover of two Israeli captives' remains, indicating their role in implementing the ceasefire-related prisoner exchange.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed by Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The closure of Rafah limits humanitarian access to Gaza, especially through the southern route, and its potential reopening is contingent on prisoner remains being returned.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that daily food supplies to Gaza remain critically low at 750 metric tonnes—well below the 2,000-tonne target—due to only two border crossings being open. The crossings at Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara allow limited aid entry, mostly to the south and center of Gaza. Despite expanding food distribution points to 26, the WFP still falls short of its goal of 145 points. The US-brokered ceasefire under Donald Trump is seen as essential for enabling aid access, particularly in northern Gaza, where aid is only reaching via the south. Hamas has committed to returning 13 of 28 captives' bodies, with two more to be delivered, which may facilitate future openings of crossings. The WFP notes that food deliveries are sufficient for only half a million people for two weeks, and many Gazans are storing food due to fears of renewed conflict, highlighting a severe and worsening humanitarian crisis.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
